intro: Mesothema trilobum, commonly known as the three-lobed mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of various host trees. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and is characterized by its small, leathery leaves and distinctive three-lobed foliage. The plant produces small, white or yellowish flowers that are often clustered together, followed by fleshy, berry-like fruits. It is native to parts of Africa and is often found in forested areas where it relies on its host for water and nutrients. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly impact the health of its host trees if left unchecked.
